Award.AwardTitle: A Laboratory Study to Investigate Inorganic and Organic Sulfate Formation in Multiphase Processes Involving Mineral Dust and Other Metal-Containing Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on laboratory studies to better understand particulate sulfate formation from sulfur dioxide oxidation in the atmosphere. A major focus of the proposed studies will be to quantify rates and extent of sulfate formation in multiphase pathways involving mineral dust and other metal-containing aerosols as a function of pH, temperature and light.

The mechanisms for sulfate formation that will be investigated in a series of laboratory studies that include the: (1) catalytic effects of transition metal ions present in mineral and anthropogenic metal-containing dusts; (2) enhanced sulfate formation in the presence of photoactive semiconductor oxides; and (3) role of organic compounds in mineral mediated sulfate processes. In addition, new methods to investigate the chemistry within individual cloud droplets will be developed, including an optical tweezer with cavity enhanced Raman spectroscopy to investigate sulfur oxidation chemistry within micron sized single droplets containing a dust inclusion. The experiments will be done in the presence and absence of atmospherically important organic species that can react to yield organosulfates. This project will also assess the importance of surface reactivity versus bulk reactivity, important for modeling cloud processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award entitled "A Laboratory Study to Investigate Inorganic and Organic Sulfate Formation in Multiphase Processes Involving Mineral Dust and Other Metal-Containing Aerosols" focused on understanding details of chemical reactions that lead to the formation of inorganic sulfate and organosulfate in the atmosphere.  The rationale behind these studies is atmospheric chemistry models are unable to predict the high concentration of sulfate aerosol in the atmosphere which suggests missing mechanisms for inorganic sulfate formation. Additionally, our understanding of reactions to form organosulfur compounds in the atmosphere is also lacking.  We investigated the details for inorganic sulfate and organosulfur compounds formation using aqueous phase bulk reactors and an aerosol optical tweezer for studies of individual micron sized aerosols.  We uncovered several important findings including: (1) organic compounds present in aqueous aerosols can react in the presence of transition metal ions (either iron and manganese ions) with sulfite, the precursor to sulfate, to yield organosulfur compounds; (2) there is a competition between inorganic sulfate and organosulfur compound formation in the presence of transition metal ions that was previously unknown; (3)  sulfur oxidation in individual micron sized aqueous aerosols occurred at rates that were 1-2 orders of magnitude faster than the reaction in the bulk aqueous phase suggesting surface effects play a role and; (4) pH impacts the aqueous phase chemistry of both inorganic sulfate and organosulfur formation.  The research resulted in several scientific papers published in high quality journals. Overall, the broader impact of the research is to provide a better scientific basis of understanding of sulfur oxidation chemistry and organosulfur formation in the atmosphere.  In addition, the grant provided undergraduate and graduate students with the opportunity to gain expertise on advanced instrumentation including high resolution mass spectrometry and cavity enhanced Raman spectroscopy.
